episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a variety of intriguing topics, including the global popularity of Tupperware parties, the theatrical trend of train scenes in 19th-century plays, the unique sleeping habits of walruses, and the rediscovery of a lost horror film due to a cataloging error.

facts.fact: In 2016, Tupperware claimed to be holding a party somewhere in the world every 1.3 seconds.
In 1868, there were five different plays on in London's West End simultaneously where a train burst onto the stage and threatened to run somebody over.
When it wants to sleep, a walrus will sometimes hook its tusks onto a small iceberg and sleep while floating along in the water.
For many years, the horror film The Unknown was missing because the last surviving print was accidentally placed into a pile of hundreds of film cans all marked unknown.
